OVERVIEW


This seminar is intended for anyone interested in gaining a deeper understanding of how bulk power transmission systems work. This would include economists, attorneys, and other non-technical professionals working in the electric power industry, as well as engineers and other technically educated personnel who are relatively new to the intricacies of the bulk electric power system. It is also useful for older hands who could benefit from a brief review.
 
The Bulk Power Transmission System: How it Works and How to Make it More Reliable should be particularly relevant for market participants, since a better understanding of the transmission system and how it functions will lead to more efficient use of resources and avoidance of unnecessary costs.
 
The seminar will cover the fundamental nature of electricity, why power flows the way it does, synchronous interconnections (grids), and how electric power systems really work. Topics will include voltage and current, real and reactive power, and transient stability. Reliability and its balance with economics will be discussed, along with 
Transmission Transfer Capabilities and how they are determined. Major attention will also be given to reliability standards and criteria, and the prevention of blackouts – especially within the context of the Energy Policy Act of 2005. The development of the North American electric grids will be briefly described, along with the critically important roles of control areas, RTOs and ISOs, Regional Reliability Councils, NERC – and the emerging role of the ERO.
 
The seminar is based on courses previously conducted for the following organizations: BC Hydro, Cegelec ESCA (Bellevue, WA), U.S. Department of Defense, FERC Staff, Florida PSC Staff, Florida Reliability Coordinating Council, ISONew England Board, Kansas City Power & Light, Oglethorpe Electric Co., Mappcor (St. Paul, MN), Mirant Corporation (Atlanta), Nebraska Society of Professional Engineers, New York State Reliability Council, New York State Public Service Commission, and ITCTransmission.
